exercise: Vibrations
Mechanical waves where the medium moves perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation.
Frequency (f)
The bending of sound waves when they change direction as they pass from one medium to another.
Amplitude (A)
The distance between two successive crests (or troughs) of a wave, measured in meters.
Period (T)
The use of sound waves to facilitate spoken interactions and underpins technologies like telephones and speakers.
Waves
The time taken to complete one full cycle of vibration, calculated as the inverse of frequency.
Mechanical Waves
The application of sound waves in ultrasound technology to create images of internal body structures.
Transverse Waves
The process where materials convert sound waves into heat, with soft materials absorbing sound better than hard surfaces.
Longitudinal Waves
Waves that require a medium (like air, water, or solid objects) to propagate.
Electromagnetic Waves
A type of mechanical wave produced by vibrating objects, requiring a medium (usually air) to travel.
Wavelength (λ)
Mechanical waves where the medium moves parallel to the direction of wave propagation, such as sound waves.
Speed (v)
The number of complete vibrations or cycles that occur in one second, measured in hertz (Hz).
Sound Waves
The occurrence when sound waves bounce off a surface, creating echoes.
Reflection
The manipulation of sound waves in acoustics for improved sound quality in various venues.
Refraction
The distance traveled per unit time by a wave, calculated using the formula v = f × λ.
Absorption
A repeated back-and-forth motion of an object about its equilibrium position.
Medical Imaging
Waves that do not require a medium and can travel through a vacuum.
Communication
A disturbance that travels through space and matter, transferring energy without the permanent displacement of the medium.
Sound Engineering
The maximum distance the object moves from its equilibrium position; higher amplitude indicates louder sounds.
